comments:
After pressing undo after dropping a component as per the instructions in
JVELAYT08, I tried Redo.  The redo operation fired our "disco" scenario with
every component being removed/added repeatedly.  After a minute or two of this,
the remote vm crashed with an out of memory exception, which causes an error
dialog to pop up to the user - "Remote VM terminated too soon"

Stack trace that showed up in the .log after doing this.  All of this was the
result of pressing redo:

Seems like this problem can occur at any time our "disco" scenario occurs.  I
just got the VM crash with errors similar to the first stack trace by reverting
the source in a modified file.

Still easy to reproduce problem and sometimes cause the vm to crash.  Open
SWTGrid from JVELAYT08 on Linux/GTK.  Drop a Label between the Foo label and the
text field.  Hit Undo.  Hit Redo.  Tons of errors will be logged, and the canvas
will be cleared.  You'll get error messages when closing the file, and when
exiting Eclipse.  This occurs with the latest code from cvs.

When you get a jvm crash like that there should be a dump in the working

Fixed so that we don't get out of memory, BUT don't know why we did. I think I
just masked it so that other situations may cause it. All I did was when a
control is added to Composite anywhere but the end, I changed it to use
moveAbove instead of removing all of the controls and then recreating them
again. I don't know why that fixes the out of memory in the image grabber, but
we don't get it now.

doesn't clean up well. Like can a GC not occur during the native code and if too
fast it can't clean up the old image copies.
